body.p:
I have been so much engaged since
the rect of yours dated 9th Feby that I could not find
time to reply thereto untill this moment—The
commencement of your Letter gave me much pain
as it was far, very far from my thoughts when I wrote
to you concerning the B. H. B Society—to wound your
feelings in the slightest degree—all that I wished
to know from you was whether the article that you
inserted in your Periodical was an official one—and
whether the party who sent it had omitted part of the
minutes ignorantly which would have been likely enough
if it had been conveyed to you from a private source
Rest assured my dear sir I have too high an opinion of
you to suppose for one moment that you yourself (to use
your own words) would be guilty of such meanness as
to insert only a part of the minutes—

I will as briefly as possible give you my reasons for asking
you for the information—when the B. H. B. Society was
first instituted, a resolution was passed (at least so I am
informed) electing all the Hebrew in New York Honorary Members
and Letters were sent accordingly informing us of such
resolution &c &c The one I received was “word for word” the
same as yours—I felt that an honorary membership
would not be of any value to a charitable Institution
and in my reply to their Letter I told them so at the same
time requesting them to admit me as a pay member. I received another a Letter in answer accepting me as a
subscriber with sundry compliments &c &c—
Now my dear sir judge my surprise on reading the
extract of the minutes in the “Occident”

and I ask you whether it is not an insult
to my Brother Hebrew as well as to myself
to see a partial statement of the minutes
published making it appear (if officially sent)
that Mr Isaacs is the only Hebrew that that the
B. H. B. Society think worthy of their notice—
for my own part I read it in this way that it
was another link added to the chain of “quack
advertisements” that you had innocently inserted
in your paper to land a particular person and
his patrons—or maybe it was or is intended to be
the commencement of a new series—

It is supposed that either Mr Godfrey or Mr Isaacs
or both together sent you the particulars—whoever
the party may be they have incurred the censure
of the committee in consequence at least so one I am
informed by one of the managers—

You will probably receive a new notice “from the Board
what it may be I know not there is however only one
course open to them that will satisfy me—and that
is to publish in your work. That the 1st article sent
was without the sanction of their Board—that it
was a false statement giving the reason why &c

You entirely mistake me if you think I wish to
appear in print in this matter in the shape of
puffery—I therefore do not comply with your
well meaning request viz to send you my Letters
for insertion—In respect to the “Occident”
a work of inestimable value in my eyes I would
I had the power of increasing its circulation, but the
majority of my congregation are opposed to it and were
so when I arrived in america owing I believe to the

numerous articles that have been inserted therein complimentary
to Mr Isaacs whom they despise—and this last
article is not likely to diminish the prejudice—

I regret exceedingly that you did not publish
the communications relative to the Ladies singing
but nevertheless I sincerely believe you
suppressed them with the purest motives

I have not as yet informed the Ball Committee
of the Donation & Tickets but I will attend to
it either to day or to morrow
